fields.description:
Currently, you only get the "release" button on the done column of a Kanban board.

In Scrum, you get to plan your versions better (across multiple sprints). But there is no "release" button on each version. It seems the only way to release a version is to do it from the "Manage Versions" page.

From a Scrum board, it takes multiple clicks to get to the "Manage Versions" page - and it's not clearly signposted that you need to / how to get there.

This seems stupid. You can create versions, and edit version details from the plan mode of a Scrum board.

You should at least be able to get to the "Manage Versions" page with one click from the Versions panel on the the Scrum board, or release a version directly from the board.
fields.summary: Improve releasing versions from a scrum board

fields.description:
As an admin, I'm used to Jira warning me about things before I delete them.  If I delete a label, or a fix version, it tells me how many issues are using it before letting me delete it.

When I create an Agile Board, it creates a filter in the background.  I didn't think about this or remember the name.  Later, I was looking at my filters and couldn't remember what those simply named filters were for... so I deleted them.

POOF!  My boards were gone.

1- why can't a board exist without a filter in some state so that I could re-add a filter
2- why isn't there a warning "Deleting this filter will delete this board"

It was 20 minutes before I noticed the boards were gone, then I had to rebuild and reconfigure those boards (which took an hour).
fields.summary: No warning when deleting filter used by board

fields.description:
1) Go to a project's "work" view, with no quick filters selected.
2) Expand all swimlanes.
3) Collapse the first ten swimlanes.
4) Turn on a quick filter, for example, the one named "Person X".
5) See the first ten issues are collapsed, even though they're not the same ones you collapsed in step 3.

It seems that the swimlane collapse is keeping a count from top of display, not based on issue ID.  Which can lead to meetings missing things because it shows something collapsed that they didn't actually collapse previously.
fields.summary: Swimlane toggle state is incorrectly based on index rather than swimlane id

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently (at least with 6.2), fields added to the [Issue Detail view|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Configuring+the+Issue+Detail+View] are always shown, regardless of whether they have a value or not. Fields without value are usually shown as {color:gray}_None_{color} or  {color:gray}_No content_{color}.

We use some custom fields (mostly text) to add additional informations for our developers; which may not be known/available or relevant for every issue. Along with other fields, this turns out to add a lot of fields that just show "No Content" before the relevant parts start.
The Detail view would end up a lot more compact and terse if just the entered information is shown, rather than everything thats configured.

One field that already does that is the Epic field (provided by GH/Agile), which is not shown when the issue is not part of an Epic.

Depending on what you think of that, empty fields should either be hidden by default (which is probably easier to implement and understand) or configurable from the Board management page (which makes things more flexible, but is probably more difficult to maintain/understand).
fields.summary: As a GH/Agile User, I would like to hide empty fields in the Issue Detail view

Because Classic boards are quite fit for our project management, and Classic Chart Borad is much powerful and useful than current rapid board. fields.description:
When managing cross projects rapid board, user would like to hide certain version off the board to avoid confusion for the product owner.

Use case:

* https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=560&view=planning&selectedIssue=CONF-31106&versions=visible

Similar to our own board, it shows all the versions from all project which is a bit confusing. User should be able to select which project's version to refer to.

Actual quotation from customer based on this use case:

{quote}
The product owner has visibility over the ongoing sprint which contains tickets from both projects, can rank CONF tickets up to fix them faster, but can't really use the release management part of the board as the version tab is full of Confluence fixversions. If they'd add CQ-13 to a CQ fixversion, it was quite uncomfortable. You should see the next fixversion you want to release on top of the list. Even if the board had a quickfilter to hide CONF tickets to do the release planning, the CONF fixversions remain.
{quote}

*Additional Information*

Helpful customer also feedback that alternative to this is by implementing the hide based on the quick filter query, meaning when searching for project = projectA, the project B version will be hidden.
fields.summary: Ability to Hide Version on Multiple Projects Rapid Board

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Classic boards, in terms of information, were better than the new burndown chart.

We've lost some important information. On Classic Boards we had 5 (colored lines), besides forecasts, with lots of information such as:
1) Remaining Values
2) Remaining Values - Ongoing (dotted line)
3) Remaining Values - Trend (dashed line)
4) Guideline (solid line)
5) Team effort - Completed (solid line)
6) Team effort - Ongoing (dotted line)
7) Estimate accuracy (solid line)
8) Estimate accuracy - Ongoing (dotted line)

The next ones were extremely important for us:
9) Required daily burndown rate (solid line)
10) Required daily burndown rate - Ongoing (dotted line)

Please Atlassian, consider to putting the above information back on the new Burndown Chart.
fields.summary: As a PMO responsible for monitoring projects, mainly burndown charts, it would be great if the information presented on classic burndown could be also presented on the new burndown chart (i.e. [Agile Sprint Burndown Gadget]).

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We are using rapid board (SCRUM option) to control our sprints.

Instead of using story points, we've decided to use original estimate as the base (effort) for our burndown. However, the original estimate is not directly defined on the stories. Instead of that, we detail our stories in subtasks, we inform the original estimate (effort) for all the subtasks and, after that, JIRA just INDIRECTLY accumulates the sum of its subtasks as the story's original estimate.

The problem is (please see screenshots attached):
- Scrum Board (Plan mode) does not show the sum of estimated hours on the respective spot.
- Due that, Scrum Board (Report mode) - Velocity Chart - also does not show the chart with the information registered. The bar chart demonstrates no information, because it does not recognize the amount of hours (remaining / registered) on subtasks.

After a quick test, I've discovered:
- The features mentioned above ONLY WORKS if the hour estimates (original time estimate) were informed DIRECTLY on the stories. It means, a story WITH NO subtasks.

In short, this situation does not fit for us. We really need to decompose our stories in subtasks and, after that, simply let the scrum rapid board (no matter the mode [plan | work | report]) do its job.

Finally, if you need more information, please just let a comment.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Scrum Board does not show sum of Estimated Hours when Stories have sub-tasks

Once JAG is disabled or stalled, all boards are disabled.

h3.Workaround

# Increase the plugin start timeout from default 60 seconds to 300 seconds by specifying the startup parameter *-Datlassian.plugins.enable.wait=300*. For a better description please see the Workaround on [JIRA System Plugin Timeout While Waiting for Plugins to Enable|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+System+Plugin+Timeout+While+Waiting+for+Plugins+to+Enable]. Note that if you do not specify the increased timeout, you will likely run into the same problem when you try updating the plugin to a newer version in UPM.
# Restart JIRA. This should enable back JIRA Agile
# If JIRA Agile boards are missing, perform a re-index to bring back all the missing board.

(!) So far Atlassian still unable to reproduce this behaviour explicitly, this bug ticket is created to keep track how many users are affected and find a common pattern to reproduce the bug.

fields.description:
In JIRA 5.2.5 (it's missing from the Affects Version/s field) with GreenHopper, the Burndown Chart for our RapidBoard is not accounting for an increase in estimated time remaining. 

h5.Steps to Reproduce
# Create SCRUM RapidBoard (we used a filter)
# Create a Sprint
# Create an issue with an estimated time remaining of 4h
# Add issue to the Sprint
# Start the Sprint
# Log 4h of work against the issue and set the remaining time to 3h (increasing the total estimate from 4h to 7h)
# View Burndown Chart on Plan screen of Sprint

h5.Expected Result
* Burndown chart shows 4h logged, and a remaining time of +3h
* Red line (remaining time) vectors up

h5.Actual Result
* Burndown chart shows 4h logged, and a remaining time of -1h
* Red line (remaining time) vectors down
fields.summary: Burndown chart for RapidBoard does not account for increase in estimated time

fields.description:
Hi,
We are happy consumers of Jira and Greenhopper.
I would like to suggest a feature.
Basically, there is no need to compare between teams. Each team calculates its velocity differently and acts different.
Still, we can measure level of commitment of each team and use this as a comparison point between teams and a measurement that combine several existing measurements and appreciate it's level relative to other teams.

For exampls - I would like to calculate level of commitment based on the velocity chart + amount of changes during the sprint (added and removed issues). 

Thanks!
Michal.
<michalep@liveperson.com>
fields.summary: Suggestion for new feature - team commitment chart

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
The layout of each individual card (ticket) in the kanban board of JIRA Agile is kind of large (although not containing much information). This means that if a column has many cards the height of the layout soon gets too big for one screen, which forces the user to do a lot of scrolling, which in turn makes the board hard to overview. 

I suggest adding a feature to let the user chose between a nomal and a contracted layot for the kanban and scrum boards in JIRA Agile. In the contracted layout the cards should look more like they do in the backlog or 
planning view. This feature would make the boards much more usable to us!
fields.summary: Contracted layout of cards in JIRA Agile boards

Is there any way to avoid this happening, because it's quite frustrating!

fields.description:
Hello. I've been getting increasingly frustrated with the short time-outs that are occurring on our OnDemand Jira instance. I don't know how long it is, because it seems intermittent - I typically am having to log in 3 or 4 times a day, yet i can leave my computer for the evening, come back in the morning and i'm still logged in which makes little sense to me. 
According to this post ( https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/44993/can-you-change-the-default-session-timeout-length ) the way to get this increased is by raising a support ticket, so that's what i'm doing.

Please can you set our session time-out to something more reasonable, such as 6 or ideally 12 hours. Thanks!
fields.summary: Please increase our On-Demand Session Time Out

fields.description:
I had a user story that I removed from a sprint, but now I can not see it in Plan Mode to add it to another sprint. This user story has a new workflow associated to it and is in Needs Acceptance, but is NOT Resolved or Closed. This is the second time this has happened. You can get to the user story by searching for it, but can not see it in Plan Mode or on the Agile Board even though it shows the sprint in the individual issue.  I also had a sprint disappear.  A user story from one project was moved to another project and it showed up on the Agile board with the sprint name from the previous project.  The team kept this sprint and kept stacking it, but when the sprint was removed from the previous project it deleted it in the current project and all the items moved to the backlog.  This should not happen.  If a user story is transferred from one project to another it should go to backlog and not create a bogus sprint.

Is there anyway to get the hidden user stories to appear on the Agile board or on Plan mode?
fields.summary: User stories that appear hidden on the Agile board and in Plan mode

fields.description:
h3. Summary

In certain situations when attempting to update an issue through SOAP or in the GUI, the below error is thrown:

{{customfield_xxxxx=Epic with name 'TEST-1' is not unique}}

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Setup an instance so that it has epics with the following IssueKey configurations:
* TEST-1
* TEST-10

Update an issue using SOAP's UpdateIssue:

{code:xml}
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:soap="http://soap.rpc.jira.atlassian.com" xmlns:soapenc="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/">
   <soapenv:Header/>
   <soapenv:Body>
      <soap:updateIssue soapenv:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/">
         <in0 xsi:type="xsd:string">efdf6949a440090fbc4c7a9cef2f9c5e9bae57b4</in0>
         <in1 xsi:type="xsd:string">TEST-1</in1>
         <in2 xsi:bean="http://beans.soap.rpc.jira.atlassian.com">
			<RemoteFieldValue>
				<id>description</id>
				<values>
					<values>
						Test 123
					</values>
				</values>
			</RemoteFieldValue>
         </in2>
      </soap:updateIssue>
   </soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>
{code}

(i) Get in0 from the login method and replace in1 with the appropriate issuekey.

h3. Expected Results

The issue is updated.

h3. Actual Results

The above error is thrown.

h3. Workaround

Cloning the issue and closing the original can help with the problem as it will move the issuekey out of the matching range. For example, if TEST-10 is cloned into TEST-21 it will no longer conflict with TEST-1.

h3. Notes

This is also covered in further detail in ["Epic with name 'xxxx' is not unique" error when trying to add an issue to an epic|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=395706948].
fields.summary: Epic with name is not unique error displayed

Example of macro on the wiki
{jiraissues:title=Theme/Epic/Story within Sprint17|columns=type;key;summary;component;status;assignee;sprint;fixVersion;Story Points;Epic Link;rank|url=https://jira.COMPANYXYZ.com/jira/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/20533/SearchRequest-20533.xml?tempMax=1000}

fields.description:
As a Program Manager I would like to have access to a basic Agile Board Report that displays a table of information on the no. of open tasks per person per sprint along with the total task hrs for the tasks of that assignee.

This request has come up from tens of people within my organisation and is crippling our ability to have quick access to this information without having to perform an extract of information from a sprint to excel where the data is transformed and then placed on a wiki for the team to view it.

Table Column headers required;
i-Assignee
ii-Total Task Count  (for that assignee)
iii-Original Estimate (hrs)   (for all tasks assigned to that assignee)
iv-Time Spent (hrs)   (for all tasks assigned to that assignee)
v-Remaining Estimate (hrs)   (for all tasks assigned to that assignee)
vi-Remaining Days in Sprint
vii-Original Assignee Capacity to the Sprint
vii-% Assignee Capacity Remaining

The first 5 pieces of information comes directly from jira but the last 3 are outside of jira.
In an ideal world I would like to define all 8 pieces of information in jira but if the first 5 could be available I would be a great start.
fields.summary: Sprint Report per Assignee to return total task count and total task hours

*Steps to Reproduce:*

# Install 2 new JIRA Instance with latest Agile on different language.
# Create a new Scrum Board with its project.
# Create stories and assigned into an epic.
# Insert value on the Story Point field.
# Do an XML Backup and do the import in the other JIRA Instance with different language.

*Expected Results:*

The project import will be successful, the JIRA Agile custom field and Issue types will be automatically translated into the target Instance language.

*Actual Results:*

The project import cannot be done, because the JIRA Agile custom fields and Issue Types are still in English.

*Associated Information:*

- [How to Unlock a Locked Field|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GHKB/How+to+unlock+a+Locked+field]

*Notes:*

- After unlocking the custom field using above KB and trasnlate it, the project import is still reject it.
- Changing the JIRA Instance default language still makes the custom field name not changing, including the Issue Types.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
According to our documentation on [Using JIRA Agile Simplified Workflow|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/AGILE/Using+JIRA+Agile+Simplified+Workflow]:

{quote}
Simplified Workflow:

Has three default steps for Scrum boards: To Do, In Progress, Done.

Has four default steps for Kanban boards: Backlog, Selected for Development, In Progress, Done.
{quote}

If you create a board and a project through JIRA Agile and choose the simplified workflow, those statuses will be created in the workflow associated to the project.

However, if you create the project through JIRA, create a JIRA Agile board and simplify the workflow, those statuses are not created. The workflow will contain the following statuses: Open, In Progress, Resolved, Reopened, Closed, for both Kanban and Scrum boards.
fields.summary: Simplifying a workflow in an existing project  doesn't create the statuses mentioned in the documentation

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

* Create a brand new project that uses *jira* default workflow
* Create a version in this project
* Create 5 issues, add them to the version you have created, and transition them to have the following statuses:

1 - Open
2 - Reopened
3 - In Progress
4 - Resolved
5 - Closed

* Go to Agile -> Classic, and access planning or chart boards. The progress bar on the right side of the screen will display how many issues are in "To Do", "In Progress" and "Done". It will display 2 issues as "To Do", one issue "In Progress" and 2 issues "Done". 

* Edit the task board mapping (Tools -> Configuration -> Task Board mapping), keeping only "Open" status in "To Do", "In Progress" status in "In Progress" and "Closed" status in "Done" 

* Check the progress bar again. It now shows 1 issue "To Do", 3 issues "In Progress" and 1 issue "Done".

Expected behavior: 1 issue "To Do", 1 issue "In Progress" and 1 issue "Done". The statuses that are not mapped should not be considered as "In Progress"
fields.summary: Agile Classic Project Progress Gadget doesn't work correctly when all the statuses are not mapped to the board
